prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: COSMOS J100135.60 COSMOS J095906.40
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Detect CO(7-6) and CI(2-1) simultaneously in two high-z main-sequence star-forming galaxies COSMOS J100135.60 and COSMOS J095906.40.
COSMOS J100135.60 has a redshift z=1.802, COSMOS J095906.40 has a redshift z=1.6746. The CO(7-6) in the two sources are at 287.884299 GHz and 301.597176 GHz respectively, with a distance of ~13 GHz. These lines can exactly be covered by the lower sideband (LSB) and upper sideband (USB) of band 7 respectively. So the two sources can share one common tuning and common calibration. The CI(2-1) line is close to CO(7-6) and can also be well covered.
However, ALMA OT spectral line mode seems will automatically tune the LO frequency according to source redshift, and hence make the number of tunings to be 2, and calibration time also doubled. We do not want ALMA OT automatically tune to different LO for the two sources here, because their line centers are already well matched to LSB and USB (one at LSB, another at USB, respectively). So they should actually share one common tuning and calibration. To achieve this, we set the velocity of COSMOS J100135.60 and COSMOS J095906.40 to 0. Also, this will not affect the imaging from uv-plane to image-plane, because we fix the representative frequency to the rest-frame CO(7-6) frequency for all sources.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We are planing to simultaneously observe CO(7-6) and [CI](3P2-3P1) in one tuning. The two line center frequencies are seperated by 0.96-1.00 GHz for sources at z=1.67-1.8, and we assume two lines have same line width as observed lower-J CO lines, and select the line width as the bandwidth for the sensitivity calculation. COSMOS J100135.60 has a redshift z=1.802, COSMOS J095906.40 has a redshift z=1.6746. The CO(7-6) in the two sources are at 287.884299 GHz and 301.597176 GHz respectively, with a distance of ~13 GHz. These lines can exactly be covered by the lower sideband (LSB) and upper sideband (USB) of band 7 respectively. So the two sources can share one common tuning and common calibration. The CI(2-1) line is close to CO(7-6) and can also be well covered. To fully cover these 4 lines, we choose LSB CO(7-6) 937.5 MHz, LSB CI(2-1) 1875 MHz, USB CO(7-6) 1875 MHz, and USB CI(2-1) 937.5 MHz. This coverage will cover the full 4 line profiles according to the lower-J CO line width, and when observing each source, one sideband will be CO/CI lines, while the other sideband will be continuum. For CO/CI line spw, we select a hanning factor of 16, resulting into a velocity resolution of <= 8 km/s, and the data rate will be much lower than the limit.
According to previous PdBI CO(2-1) observations, COSMOS J100135.60 and COSMOS J095906.40 are unresolved by PdBI beam. PACS-830 The sources are strong here so we can use a slightly higher resolution.

COSMOS J100135.60 and COSMOS J095906.40 have already been observed with PdBI in CO(2-1) (Sargent et al.), the line fluxes are 1.12 Jy km/s and 1.42 Jy km/s respectively.
Both two sources are unresolved by the PdBI synthesized beam. We estimate the line flux of CO(7-6) with a conservative r72 ratio of 0.95, i.e., r72 = CO(7-6)/CO(2-1) = 0.95. This value is derived from lower LVG fitting solutions of z~1.5 BzKs (Daddi et al. 2014 Fig.10). Note that r72 for BzKs can vary from 0.95 to 2.7 which are not well constrained yet with current data. In our sample MSs are more massive than BzKs and SFRs are higher, we would expect stronger CO excitations and lines to be more easily detected.
We are planing to simultaneously observe CO(7-6) and [CI](3P2-3P1) in one tuning. The two line center frequencies are seperated by only ~1.0 GHz for sources at z~1.5, and we assume they have same line width as observed lower-J CO lines, i.e. 510 km/s for COSMOS J100135.60 and 618 km/s for COSMOS J095906.40. We select the minor line width as the bandwidth for the sensitivity calculation.
The line fluxes of [CI](3P2-3P1) for these two sources are estimated based on CO(7-6)/[CI](3P2-3P1) = 1.0. At local, the Herschel/FTS derived CO(7-6)/[CI](3P2-3P1) ratios has a mean value of 0.9 but with a tail toward higher values. At high-z (z<6) the ratio keeps around 1.0 and is no more than 2, while at z>6 several sources show very high ratio values, but since our sources are lower-z, and our CO(7-6) r72 line ratio are conservative, we will still use a CO(7-6)/[CI](3P2-3P1) ratio of 1.0.
Because these sources have already been well detected in two lower-J CO lines, here we only ask for a CO(7-6) and CI(2-1) detection of S/N = 3. We would expect these high-z SFGs have higher CO excitation than local galaxies, as indicated by the CO line ratio versus radiation field <U> correlation (Daddi et al. 2014), thus the S/N will likely be larger.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: COSMOS J100018.21 COSMOS_J095906.40 PACS-325
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Simultaneously detect: CO(7-6) and [CI](3P2-3P1) in COSMOS J100018.21+023456.7 CO(5-4) in COSMOS J095906.40 CO(5-4) in PACS-325
The CO(7-6) and [CI](3P2-3P1) in COSMOS J100018.21+023456.7 are exactly fall in the upper sideband (USB) when the CO(5-4) in COSMOS J095906.40 and CO(5-4) in PACS-325 exactly fall in the lower sideband (LSB). The tuning is well designed. Source redshifts are H_alpha and lower-J CO confirmed.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We are planing to simultaneously observe CO(7-6) and [CI](3P2-3P1) in one tuning. The two line center frequencies are seperated by 0.77 GHz for sources at z=2.479, and we assume two lines have same line width as observed lower-J CO lines, and select the line width as the bandwidth for the sensitivity calculation. We select a total bandwidth of 1875 MHz with an averaging factor of 16, providing velocity resolution of about 10 km/s. Data rate is within limit.

The source is unresolved according to previous observations, with CO size < 2" (Lentati et al. 2014). Sources are relatively faint, especially J100018.21 is the faintest, thus we do not want to use too high resolution.

COSMOS J100018.21 have already been observed with JVLA in CO(1-0) (Lentati et al. 2014), the line flux is 0.076 Jy km/s.
COSMOS J100018.21 is unresolved by the JVLA synthesized beam, CO size <2". We reasonably estimate the line flux of CO(7-6) with a r71 ratio of 3.0, i.e., r71 = CO(7-6)/CO(1-0) = 3.0. This value is derived from lower LVG fitting solutions of z~1.5 BzKs (Daddi et al. 2014 Fig.10). Note that r71 for BzKs can vary from 2.81 to 7.9 which are not well constrained yet with current data. In our sample MSs are more massive than BzKs and SFRs are higher, we would expect stronger CO excitations and lines to be more easily detected.
COSMOS J095906.40 and PACS-325 are unresolved by lower-J CO observations. We estimate the line flux of CO(5-4) with a conservative r52 ratio of 1.85, i.e., r52 = CO(5-4)/CO(2-1) = 1.85. This value is derived from lower LVG fitting solutions of z~1.5 BzKs (Daddi et al. 2014 Fig.10). See also their Fig.11 r52 versus various properties. The ratio 1.85 is relatively conservative but reasonable. In our sample MSs are more massive than BzKs and SFRs are higher, we would expect stronger CO excitations and lines to be more easily detected.
We are planing to simultaneously observe CO(7-6) and [CI](3P2-3P1) of COSMOS J100018.21 and CO(5-4) of COSMOS J095906.40 and PACS-325 in one tuning. The line frequencies are: COSMOS J095906.40 CO(5-4) restfreq=576.267931 obsfreq=215.459482 GHz PACS-325 CO(5-4) restfreq=576.267931 obsfreq=216.886688 GHz COSMOS J100018.21 CO(7-6) restfreq=806.651806 obsfreq=231.863123 GHz COSMOS J100018.21 CI(2-1) restfreq=809.341970 obsfreq=232.636381 GHz This exactly suits the LSB USB of band 6: sideband width 5 GHz, sideband separation 10 GHz.
We assume they have similar line width as observed lower-J CO lines. We select PACS-325 line intensity divided by S/N=3 and line width as the request sensitivity and bandwidth for the sensitivity calculation.
The line flux of [CI](3P2-3P1) for the source is estimated based on CO(7-6)/[CI](3P2-3P1) = 1.0. At local, the Herschel/FTS derived CO(7-6)/[CI](3P2-3P1) ratios has a mean value of 0.9 but with a tail toward higher values. At high-z (z<6) the ratio keeps around 1.0 and is no more than 2, while at z>6 several sources show very high ratio values, but since our sources are lower-z, we will still use a CO(7-6)/[CI](3P2-3P1) ratio of 1.0.
Because this source has already been well detected in CO(1-0) lines, here we only ask for a CO(7-6) and CI(2-1) detection of S/N = 3. We would expect it to have higher CO excitation than local galaxies, as indicated by the CO line ratio versus radiation field <U> correlation (Daddi et al. 2014), thus the S/N will likely be larger.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: PACS-325 PACS-867
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Simultaneously detect CO(7-6) and [CI](3P2-3P1) in PACS-325 and PACS-867. The redshifed lines of the two sources exactly fall on the LSB and USB of band 7 respectively.
PACS-325 is at z=1.657. PACS-867 is at z=1.568. The CO(7-6)/[CI](3P2-3P1) doublet of PACS-325 is at ~304 GHz, while the CO(7-6)/[CI](3P2-3P1) doublet of PACS-867 is at ~315 GHz, which means we can use one tuning for the two sources, with lower sideband (LSB) of band 7 covering ~304 GHz and upper sideband (USB) of band 7 covering ~315 GHz, the space between LSB and USB is 8 GHz for band 7.
However, ALMA OT spectral line mode seems will automatically tune the LO frequency according to source redshift, and hence make the number of tunings to be 2, and calibration time also doubled. We do not want ALMA OT automatically tune to different LO for the two sources here, because their line centers are already well matched to LSB and USB (one at LSB, another at USB, respectively). So they should actually share one common tuning and calibration. To achieve this, we set the velocity of PACS-867 and PACS-325 to 0, but keep in mind that the true velocity of PACS-867 is not the same as PACS-325. Also, this will not affect the imaging from uv-plane to image-plane, because we fix the representative frequency to the rest-frame CO(7-6) frequency for all sources.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We are planing to simultaneously observe CO(7-6) and [CI](3P2-3P1) in one tuning. The two line center frequencies are seperated by 1.01 GHz for sources at z~1.5, and we assume two lines have same line width as observed lower-J CO lines, and select the line width as the bandwidth for the sensitivity calculation. We select a total bandwidth of 1875 MHz with an averaging factor of 16, providing velocity resolution of about 8 km/s.
The source is unresolved according to previous observations. PACS-325 has CO size < 4" (Silverman et al. 2015 in prep.). Sources are relatively faint thus we do not want to use too high resolution.

PACS-325 and PACS-867 have already been observed with ALMA in CO(2-1) and PdBI in CO(5-4). PACS-325 CO(2-1) is 0.28 \pm 0.06 Jy km/s, but is undetected in CO(5-4) (<2.5 Jy km/s). PACS-867 CO(2-1) is 0.46 \pm 0.04 Jy km/s, and CO(5-4) is marginly detected with 0.9 \pm 0.3 Jy km/s.
Both two sources are unresolved by the PdBI synthesized beam.
For PACS-325, we estimate the line flux of CO(7-6) with a r72 ratio corresponding to its very high <U>, i.e., r72 = CO(7-6)/CO(2-1) = 1.5. See panel(b) of Fig.3 in the scientific justification. This value is derived from lower+higher LVG fitting solutions of z~1.5 BzKs (Daddi et al. 2014 Fig.10 left and right panels). r72 for BzKs can vary from 0.95 to 2.7 which are not well constrained yet with current data. The large <U> of PACS-325 indicates stronger CO excitations and the lines will be detected at least S/N=3.
For PACS-867, we estimate the line flux of CO(7-6) with a conservative r72 ratio of 0.95, i.e., r72 = CO(7-6)/CO(2-1) = 0.95. This value is derived from lower LVG fitting solutions of z~1.5 BzKs (Daddi et al. 2014 Fig.10). Note that r72 for BzKs can vary from 0.95 to 2.7 which are not well constrained yet with current data. In our sample MSs are more massive than BzKs and SFRs are higher, we would expect stronger CO excitations and lines to be more easily detected.
We are planing to simultaneously observe CO(7-6) and [CI](3P2-3P1) in one tuning. The two line center frequencies are seperated by 1.01 GHz for sources at z~1.5, and we assume they have same line width as observed lower-J CO lines, i.e. 764 km/s for PACS-325 and 472 km/s for PACS-867. We select a bandwidth of 760 km/s for the sensitivity calculation because PACS-325 predicted line flux is weaker than PACS-867. When PACS-325 is detected at S/N=3, PACS-867 will be detected with S/N~3.1.
The line fluxes of [CI](3P2-3P1) for these two sources are estimated based on CO(7-6)/[CI](3P2-3P1) = 1.0. At local, the Herschel/FTS derived CO(7-6)/[CI](3P2-3P1) ratios has a mean value of 0.9 but with a tail toward higher values. At high-z (z<6) the ratio keeps around 1.0 and is no more than 2, while at z>6 several sources show very high ratio values, but since our sources are lower-z, we will still use a CO(7-6)/[CI](3P2-3P1) ratio of 1.0.
Because these sources have already been well detected in two lower-J CO lines, here we only ask for a CO(7-6) and CI(2-1) detection of S/N = 3. We would expect it to have higher CO excitation than local galaxies, as indicated by the CO line ratio versus radiation field <U> correlation (Daddi et al. 2014), thus the S/N will likely be larger.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: PACS-164 PACS-299
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Simultaneously detect CO(7-6) and [CI](3P2-3P1) in PACS-164 and PACS-299. The two sources have the same redshift, hence can share one common tuning/velocity.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We are planing to simultaneously observe CO(7-6) and [CI](3P2-3P1) in one tuning. The two line center frequencies are seperated by 1.01 GHz for sources at z~1.5, and we assume two lines have same line width as observed lower-J CO lines, and select the line width as the bandwidth for the sensitivity calculation. We select a total bandwidth of 1875 MHz with an averaging factor of 16, providing velocity resolution of about 8 km/s.

The sources are unresolved according to previous observations. PACS-164 has CO size < 4.8", and PACS-299 has CO size < 2.4" (Silverman et al. 2015 in prep.). Sources are not very strong thus we do not want to use too high resolution.

PACS-164 has already been observed with PdBI in CO(2-1) and CO(5-4), the line fluxes are 0.61 \pm 0.11 Jy km/s and 2.254 \pm 0.745 Jy km/s respectively.
PACS-299 has the same CO redshift as PACS-164, so we observe them in one ScienceGoal. The line fluxes of already observed ALMA CO(2-1) and PdBI CO(5-4) are 0.67 \pm 0.08 Jy km/s and 1.896 \pm 0.486 Jy km/s respectively.
Both two sources are unresolved by the sythesized beam of about 5.5 arcsec. We estimate the line flux of CO(7-6) with a conservative r72 ratio of 0.95, i.e., r72 = CO(7-6)/CO(2-1) = 0.95. This value is derived from lower LVG fitting solutions of z~1.5 BzKs (Daddi et al. 2014 Fig.10). Note that r72 for BzKs can vary from 0.95 to 2.7 which are not well constrained yet with current data. In our sample MSs are more massive than BzKs and SFRs are higher, we would expect stronger CO excitations and lines to be more easily detected.
We are planing to simultaneously observe CO(7-6) and [CI](3P2-3P1) in one tuning. The two line center frequencies are seperated by 1.01 GHz for sources at z~1.5, and we assume they have same line width as observed lower-J CO lines, i.e. 894 km/s for PACS-164 and 590 km/s for PACS-299. We select a bandwidth of 894 km/s for the sensitivity calculation because PACS-164 line flux is slightly weaker than PACS-299.
The line fluxes of [CI](3P2-3P1) for these two sources are estimated based on CO(7-6)/[CI](3P2-3P1) = 1.0. At local, the Herschel/FTS derived CO(7-6)/[CI](3P2-3P1) ratios has a mean value of 0.9 but with a tail toward higher values. At high-z (z<6) the ratio keeps around 1.0 and is no more than 2, while at z>6 several sources show very high ratio values, but since our sources are lower-z, we will still use a CO(7-6)/[CI](3P2-3P1) ratio of 1.0.
Because these sources have already been well detected in two lower-J CO lines, here we only ask for a CO(7-6) and CI(2-1) detection of S/N = 3. We would expect it to have higher CO excitation than local galaxies, as indicated by the CO line ratio versus radiation field <U> correlation (Daddi et al. 2014), thus the S/N will likely be larger.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: COSMOS J100156.71 PACS-819
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Simultaneously detect CO(7-6) and [CI](3P2-3P1) in COSMOS J100156.71 and [CI](3P2-3P1) in PACS-819. The 3 redshifed lines of the two sources exactly fall on the same one sideband of band 7.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We are planing to simultaneously observe CO(7-6) and [CI](3P2-3P1) in one tuning. The two line center frequencies are seperated by 1.01 GHz for sources at z~1.5, and we assume two lines have same line width as observed lower-J CO lines, and select the line width as the bandwidth for the sensitivity calculation. We select a total bandwidth of 1875 MHz with an averaging factor of 16, providing velocity resolution of about 8 km/s.

According to previous ALMA CO(2-1) observations, PACS-819 has CO size = 0.34 \pm 0.08" (Silverman et al. 2015 in prep.).
COSMOS J100156.71 is unresolved by PdBI.
Sources are very strong.

COSMOS J100156.71 has already been observed with PdBI in CO(2-1). Line flux is 1.9 Jy km/s (Sargent et al.).
PACS-819 has already been observed with ALMA in CO(2-1) and PdBI in CO(5-4), the line fluxes are 1.10 \pm 0.07 Jy km/s and 3.715 \pm 1.372 Jy km/s respectively.
PACS-819 is slightly resolved with a deconvolved source size of 0.34 \pm 0.08 arcsec.
We estimate the line flux of CO(7-6) with a conservative r72 ratio of 0.95, i.e., r72 = CO(7-6)/CO(2-1) = 0.95. This value is derived from lower LVG fitting solutions of z~1.5 BzKs (Daddi et al. 2014 Fig.10). Note that r72 for BzKs can vary from 0.95 to 2.7 which are not well constrained yet with current data. In our sample MSs are more massive than BzKs and SFRs are higher, we would expect stronger CO excitations and lines to be more easily detected.
We are planing to simultaneously observe CO(7-6) and [CI](3P2-3P1) in one tuning. The two line center frequencies are seperated by 1.01 GHz for sources at z~1.5, and we assume they have same line width as observed lower-J CO lines, i.e. 507 km/s for COSMOS J100156.71 and 592 km/s for PACS-819. We select 507 km/s as the bandwidth for the sensitivity calculation.
The line fluxes of [CI](3P2-3P1) for these two sources are estimated based on CO(7-6)/[CI](3P2-3P1) = 1.0. At local, the Herschel/FTS derived CO(7-6)/[CI](3P2-3P1) ratios has a mean value of 0.9 but with a tail toward higher values. At high-z (z<6) the ratio keeps around 1.0 and is no more than 2, while at z>6 several sources show very high ratio values, but since our sources are lower-z, we will still use a CO(7-6)/[CI](3P2-3P1) ratio of 1.0.
Because these sources have already been well detected in two lower-J CO lines, here we only ask for a CO(7-6) and CI(2-1) detection of S/N = 3. We would expect it to have higher CO excitation than local galaxies, as indicated by the CO line ratio versus radiation field <U> correlation (Daddi et al. 2014), thus the S/N will likely be larger.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: PACS-830 PACS-819
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Simultaneously detect: CO(7-6) and [CI](3P2-3P1) in PACS-830 CO(8-7) in COSMOS J100135.60 -- now not observe because too faint CO(7-6) in PACS-819
The redshifed lines of the selected sources exactly fall on the same one sideband of band 7.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We are planing to simultaneously observe CO(7-6) and [CI](3P2-3P1) in one tuning. The two line center frequencies are seperated by 1.01 GHz for sources at z~1.5, and we assume two lines have same line width as observed lower-J CO lines, and select the line width as the bandwidth for the sensitivity calculation. We select a total bandwidth of 1875 MHz with an averaging factor of 16, providing velocity resolution of about 8 km/s.

According to previous ALMA CO(2-1) observations, PACS-830 has CO size = 0.97 \pm 0.17"" (Silverman et al. 2015 in prep.).
COSMOS J100135.60 is unresolved by PdBI.
According to previous ALMA CO(2-1) observations, PACS-819 has CO size = 0.34 \pm 0.08" (Silverman et al. 2015 in prep.).
Sources are all strong here, so we choose a higher resolution of 0.3".

PACS-830 has already been observed with ALMA in CO(2-1) and PdBI in CO(5-4), the line fluxes are 1.18 \pm 0.01 Jy km/s and 2.35 \pm 0.5 Jy km/s respectively.
PACS-830 is slightly resolved with a deconvolved source size of 0.97 \pm 0.17 arcsec.
PACS-819 has already been observed with ALMA in CO(2-1) and PdBI in CO(5-4), the line fluxes are 1.10 \pm 0.07 Jy km/s and 3.715 \pm 1.372 Jy km/s respectively.
PACS-819 is slightly resolved with a deconvolved source size of 0.34 \pm 0.08 arcsec.
We estimate the line flux of CO(7-6) with a conservative r72 ratio of 0.95, i.e., r72 = CO(7-6)/CO(2-1) = 0.95. This value is derived from lower LVG fitting solutions of z~1.5 BzKs (Daddi et al. 2014 Fig.10). Note that r72 for BzKs can vary from 0.95 to 2.7 which are not well constrained yet with current data. In our sample MSs are more massive than BzKs and SFRs are higher, we would expect stronger CO excitations and lines to be more easily detected.
We are planing to perform one tuning of spectral scan, to cover these lines: PACS-830 CO(7-6) 327.640864 GHz PACS-830 CI(2-1) 328.733538 GHz PACS-819 CO(7-6) 329.784058 GHz
We assume same line width as observed lower-J CO lines, i.e. 436 km/s for PACS-830, 507 km/s for COSMOS J100156.71 and 592 km/s for PACS-819. We select 436 km/s as the bandwidth for the sensitivity calculation.
The line fluxes of [CI](3P2-3P1) for these two sources are estimated based on CO(7-6)/[CI](3P2-3P1) = 1.0. At local, the Herschel/FTS derived CO(7-6)/[CI](3P2-3P1) ratios has a mean value of 0.9 but with a tail toward higher values. At high-z (z<6) the ratio keeps around 1.0 and is no more than 2, while at z>6 several sources show very high ratio values, but since our sources are lower-z, we will still use a CO(7-6)/[CI](3P2-3P1) ratio of 1.0.
Because these sources have already been well detected in two lower-J CO lines, here we only ask for a CO(7-6) and CI(2-1) detection of S/N = 3. We would expect it to have higher CO excitation than local galaxies, as indicated by the CO line ratio versus radiation field <U> correlation (Daddi et al. 2014), thus the S/N will likely be larger.
we select a hanning factor of 16, resulting into a velocity resolution of <= 8 km/s, and the data rate will be much lower than the limit.
This MS galaxy is the strongest. We will use a highest angular resolution becuase the missing flux will be not important for this strong sources.

COSMOS J100156.71 has already been observed with PdBI in CO(2-1). Line flux is 1.9 Jy km/s (Sargent et al.).
We estimate the line flux of CO(5-4) with a conservative r52 ratio of 1.85, i.e., r52 = CO(5-4)/CO(2-1) = 1.85. This value is derived from lower LVG fitting solutions of z~1.5 BzKs (Daddi et al. 2014 Fig.10). See also their Fig.11 r52 versus various properties. The ratio 1.85 is relatively conservative but reasonable. In our sample MSs are more massive than BzKs and SFRs are higher, we would expect stronger CO excitations and lines to be more easily detected.

We are planing to observe CO(4-3) here. We use the lower-J CO line width as the bandwidth for the sensitivity calculation. We select a total bandwidth of 1875 MHz with an averaging factor of 16, providing velocity resolution of about 17 km/s. Data rate is within limit.
The source is unresolved according to previous observations, with CO size < 2" (Lentati et al. 2014). Sources are relatively faint thus we do not want to use too high resolution.

COSMOS J100018.21 have already been observed with JVLA in CO(1-0) (Lentati et al. 2014), the line flux is 0.076 Jy km/s.
COSMOS J100018.21 is unresolved by the JVLA synthesized beam, CO size <2". We estimate the line flux of CO(4-3) with a r41 ratio of 4.5, i.e., r41 = CO(4-3)/CO(1-0) = 4.5. This value is derived from lower LVG fitting solutions of z~1.5 BzKs (Daddi et al. 2014 Fig.10). Note that r41 for BzKs are relatively well constrained with current data.
we select a hanning factor of 16, resulting into a velocity resolution of <= 9 km/s, and the data rate will be much lower than the limit.
This MS galaxy is the third strongest. We will use a highest angular resolution becuase the missing flux will be not important for this strong sources.

COSMOS J100135.60 has already been observed with PdBI in CO(2-1) (Sargent et al.), the line flux is 1.12 Jy km/s.
Its CO(4-3), (5-4) are out of ALMA band. CO(6-5) is very suitable for observing.
The sources is unresolved by the PdBI synthesized beam. We estimate the line flux of CO(6-5) with a conservative r62 ratio of 1.58, i.e., r62 = CO(6-5)/CO(2-1) = 1.58. This value is derived from lower LVG fitting solutions of z~1.5 BzKs (Daddi et al. 2014 Fig.10). Note that r62 for BzKs can vary from 1.58 to 2 which are not well constrained yet with current data. In our sample MSs are more massive than BzKs and SFRs are higher, we would expect stronger CO excitations and lines to be more easily detected.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose the first CO(7-6)+CI(2-1) detections of a well defined sample of z~1.5 main-sequance (MS) and starburst (SB) galaxies, selected purely based on SFR and stellar mass with respect to the star-forming main-sequence at z~1.5. Our sample has ALMA/PdBI CO(2-1)/CO(5-4) observations, with which we start CO excitation modelings. However compared to numerous local Herschel/FTS CO SLEDs that we are studying, high-z MS and SB CO SLEDs are rather poorly sampled, which is prohibiting our understanding of the interplay between dense warm star-forming gas and star formation and interstellar radiation field intensity <U>. ALMA is the only and best opportunity to perform J>=7 CO SLED observations for our sample. We have carefully optimized the usage of ALMA wide sidebands, and will detect 23 CO/[CI] in 10 MSs+SBs within 5 hours. The new data will provide strong constraints on the gas excitation of both high-z SBs and MSs, and between local SBs/MSs. We will decompose cold+warm star-forming gas and calibrate correlation between the warm gas and <U>, SFR, galaxy "clumpiness", etc., which are all crucial for the theories and simulations of star formation.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Physics & Astronomy, Sussex, University of
Institute for the Physics and Mathematics of the Universe, The University of Tokyo
